ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A basic understanding of psychology.
I learned a lot of general knowledge and specific examples in psychology.
Survey of psychology research techniques, theories, and applications -- great for deciding which aspects of the field I want to further pursue.
A lot of introductory psychology and studies
Ive learned lots of interesting things about human behavior.
I know so much more about psychology now! It's a wide range of knowledge, and it can change from year to year, so best bet is to check out the syllabus for specifics.
I learned an overview of major psychological findings, and how they apply to real life.

I learned a little about a lot of subjects in this course, which I believe was Professor Chun's intentions. I gained a basic knowledge of many branches of social psychology while learning about a lot of prominent studies along the way.
I learned about the basic principles of psychology and famous breakthrough studies.
Introduction to Psychology, how to write a research paper effectively (short but informative), how to cover large contents effectively (learn many key words and concepts,...)
I very much have enjoyed every psychology class I have taken at Yale so far. All of the topics covered are very applicable to everyday life.
This introductory class taught basic psychology material
I learned so much about how the brain works and why people act in the way that they do for certain situations.
I big overview of all the kinds of psych you can study. It's fun and interesting, but a lot of material because it is an intro course.
I learned about psychology on a broad spectrum.

Dean Chun does a great job at covering nearly the entire textbook, and adds in personal tweaks that make the class even more engaging. Almost each lecture is a new topic, so it always stayed interesting and engaging. Because of this course, I have developed a fundamental understanding of psychology.
This is a basic introduction to psychology. You will learn all the basics you need!
I know a lot more about the human mind and tendencies when it comes to thinking about certain things in specific ways.
I fell in love with psych
Got a survey of general psychology, learned a lot about behavior, biases, and recent trends in psychology
Learned all aspects of psychology and allowed me to understand what parts of psychology that I liked.
Introduction level psychology
I learned the basics of psychology, and extremely cool studies. Something you talk about at dinner tables and everyone will find interesting.

Learned a broad introduction to psychology. Topics include: sensing, happiness, brain imaging, memory, consciousness, sleep, performance, development, language, evolutionary psychology, emotion, learning, mental illness, stress, personality, drugs, intelligence, bias, social psychology, and sustainable psychology.
Learned about basic psychology principles. Lots of bits and pieces from different elements of psychology.
A general overview of psychology, what pscyhology studies look like.
How to understand how people think about things
Intro Psychology

Intro. Psych was a very interesting, engaging course. It covered a broad range of topics that are important to the world of psychology. The lectures were so fun to go to, and the feedback on our essays was very helpful. Overall, the course professors and TF's were really great about returning assignments and being very clear with what the expectation for each assignment was.
I got a good base in psychology and am now interested in the field
I learned the basic concepts of Psychology.
Learned the basics of psych.
I thought this was a very thorough introduction to psychology. I definitely feel well acquainted to the field and ready to take the next level of classes.
Great broad intro to different areas and fundamental experiments of psychology for someone with no experience in the field
Thorough understanding of psychological studies and methods of investigation. Broad range of interesting topics that showcased many, if not all, branches of clinical and research psychology.
I learned a lot about basic psychological concepts. I also learned different techniques to persuade (manipulate) people to get them to say yes to things.
A basic understanding of a bunch of psych topics.
You learn about the basics of psychology, as the name of the course implies. Essentially, the course surveys many subareas of psychology that make up the entire science.
This course really was an intro to psychology. We learned a lot about a lot of different aspects of psychology, with a lot of real-world examples.
many different concepts in psychology I'd never encountered before
I learned about the study of my mind and how it functions.

I developed a basic understanding of core psychological processes and approaches, including memory, intelligence, behavior, and psychological disorders. I learned to apply these psychological principles to real-world events and had the opportunity to develop my scientific writing abilities as it related to different psychology topics. I gained key insights into how psychology is relevant to our everyday world.
I like psych
learn more about how to manage my emotions
I gained so much knowledge about psychology and through it, the nuances of life.
I think this was definitely a class that had practical applications. The information learned in the class is helpful for everyday activities, as well as interesting to know about psychology.
I learned a ton of "fun facts," little things that shape how I see the world. It's shocking how immediately relevant all of this material was in my day to day life.
Considering this course is an introductory class in psychology, I certainly felt that I walked away with foundational knowledge.
I learned about how the brain works and gained insight into my everyday life.
Learned studies and analyses of people's behavior that I now think about in everyday life.
I became better at following lectures and keeping up with readings.
I developed a deep knowledge of many introduction to psychology topics.
Basic knowledge of psychology
A quest into the psyche of the human mind

You really do learn a ton in this class. Between the book and the lectures you really gain a strong working knowledge of the basics of psychology. 

They also claim the TAs are super consistent about grading your essays but it really did feel somewhat arbitrary.
General knowledge of psychology, overview of different areas of the field
I became familiar with many important concepts in psychology. The material from this course is a good jumping off point for psychology students, but there isnt in-depth discussion of any one topic.
How to do a research paper, how to read a textbook, basic psych knowledge.
I got an overview of basic Psychology. I also was ball to learn how to analyze/dissect Psychology research paper.
I learned more about how psychology impacts our lives everyday
This was the first social science class that I took at Yale, and it provided me with a basis for analyzing interactions with other individuals. It was a broad overview of many psychology topics.
I learned how to read a large amount of information and choose the important information, and I learned a lot of interesting things about the mind, personalities, and socialization.
I learnt several important aspects of every day of life, such as the need to have a regular sleep schedule and to keep certain mindsets.
Introductory themes of psychology: social psychology, psychological disorders, intelligence, cognitive skills
I learned how to think to reduce stress.
I learned about the basics of psychology.
How to analyse studies and compare and synthesise findings
Analytical skills.

This is a very general survey of modern topics. Not like a history of psychology- I expected to learn freud, jung, piaget but did not. Some lectures are better than others. Great to have guest lecturers pretty often!
I learned s lot of the basic information about psychology but also a lot of the content portray issues that relate to this information and how it can be applied in the real world.

I definitely learned a fair amount about a wide range of topics in psychology ranging from neuroscience to personality research. I would say I also developed a greater understanding of how to run my own personal life based on the material that we covered.
I learned a lot of basic psychology information, mostly from selected studies that Dean Chun talked about in class.
Viewing the world through a psychological perspective
Many about psychology and the role it plays in everyday life.
I learnt about the fundamentals to psychology
I learned so much about stress about other subjects that I could apply to in my life
I learned to download the lecture slides and take copious notes on every minute detail, and to rewatch the lectures on canvas if they are available. I also learned to never trust anyone.

I gained a brief overview of different areas of Psych (social psych, intelligence, etc) and the its history and most famous figures and experiments.
Plus different looks in subjects like psychopathy and drugs with guest lecturers
I learnt about psychology, the mind, and behavior
Introduction to psychology
I learned a lot about how the brain functions and the underlying reasons for people's behavior. I find myself constantly thinking about the things I learned or read about in my everyday life.

I learned some cool things about psychology -- like very specific findings/topics. How Republicans are psychologically different than Democrats, how attraction works, etc. No general insights or skill-development.
introductory psychology and analysis
Interesting facts about how people think

Not only did I gain a great knowledge of general introductory psychology, I also learned a lot about the world around us. Professor Chun did a great job of incorporating psychology into everyday life, social issues, and personal life. Learning about the subconscious motives behind everyday actions, aggressive behaviors, drug addictions, mental health patterns, etc. was eye opening.
A great intro knowledge of psychology as a field.
Great psychology insight
I gained insight into the field of psychology and gained the ability to make informed choices on the courses I would like to take in this field and the different research branches.
Gained a deeper knowledge of human behavior and how our brain works.
Basic topics in psychology.
I learned a lot about the basic foundations of psychology and felt like I came out of the course with a good understanding of standard psychology knowledge.
Lovely
How to pace a clas with a lot of reading involved
introduction to psychology concepts, methods, and studies
Applying psychological concepts to explain real life congitive social and socialogical phenomena
Gained basic overview of the field of psychology.
Attention to detail in class and in readings
I learned how to think differently about psychology.
I learned a lot about psychology and it was a really great course to better understand trends in human behavior.
Psychology
An overview of fundamental psychology topics and pioneering research in the field.
This was a great class. Definitely would recommend anyone take, even if youre not interested in or plan to take further courses in psychology. The class is very applicable to everyday life.
I learned basic concepts about psychology.
This class was very interesting because it was very applicable to daily life.
I gained a thorough knowledge of the foundations of psychology, and a well-explored extension of each category of the subject.
I learned a lot about the various fields of psychology.
Analytical skills definitely, the way I think definitely improved by taking this course.
Memorization and analyzing my own human experience.
Basic survey of fields in psychology.

I had no psychology experience before taking this course and I felt that Professor Chun and the course structure provided a strong, broad overview of psychology's main concepts-- exactly what is set out to do.
Takiing notes
I learned about general areas in psychology and some important studies and the key conclusions from them.
The ability to research and write about psych as well as an understanding of psychology in general
I learned how to think critically about everyday components of life through a variety of psychological lenses.
You learn the basics of the human mind, no thanks to the professor. You teach yourself everything.
I learned a ton about psychology, being able to explore a field in depth that I was always really interested in, but never had a chance to study.
I learned different psychological principles and terms.
How to take a lecture class, what the study of psychology might entail, how social science lectures are

This class introduced me to the field of psychology, giving me a general understanding of human behavior and the mind. Not a typical science course, this class gave data and theories behind many relevant topics such as personality, intelligence, and emotion.
An understanding of the rudimentary psychological theory of the brain, the mind, and human behavior, and a basic understanding of how the field of psychology attains knowledge.
I learned a lot about what psychology is and the basic ways in which its applied.
This course covered a lot of interesting topics like the psychology of happiness and implicit bias. The material was quite interesting.
A lot of cursory psychology information.
This course taught me a lot about how and why people act the way they do. Theres so much information Ive learned i couldnt possibly fit in this box.
I've learned a lot about the basics of psychology, and the course covers most of the major fields in psych.
I learned about the basics of psychology and how they can be applied to everyday situations.
I learned very interesting facts that apply to my daily life.

I was given a broad overview of the various fields of psychology and how they applied to my everyday life. I both reaffirmed existing common sense and learned new psychological tricks. For instance, I learned about love from guest speaker Peter Salovey and how things like the pratfall effect can actually benefit how much people like you.
This class taught me that psychology was everywhere and that the principles learned in the class can be applied everywhere to further understand human behavior and interactions.

I learned a lot of the foundational concepts behind psychology and how to use these concepts to help myself and the people around me. I learned about the history of psychology and its still-debated place in the sciences despite the numerous advancements it has led to. The psychology behind different mental illnesses is truly fascinating, as is developmental psychology. Overall I gained so many valuable insights by taking this course and I would absolutely recommend it.
Intro psych stuff, like AP Psychology
I learned about practical skills in psychology, and gained a better understanding of the field and how it has evolved.
We learned a great deal about the mind, ranging from a cognitive science to a clinical viewpoint.
General knowledge of psychology principles and terms as well as understanding and participation in Psychology studies and their uses.
Psychology is a science. Psychology is fun. Psychology Ian relevant in everything we do! Fun very interesting class and great professor. Not a gut though!
I learned a broad overview of a variety of different psychological fields.
I learned basic psychology principles.

I was able to gain a broad range of knowledge regarding Psychology, being introduced to different areas that can be studied under such a general subject. I believe the course went into enough detail to be able to cover a lot of material.
A lot of core concepts of psychology were covered in this course.
Knowledge about basic psychology from parts of the brain to love and race relations
basic knowledge of psychological terms/concepts, important experiments, how to analyze personality/social interactions/biases/everyday phenomena through a psychological lens

Learned a lot of information that is applicable to daily life- about how our minds work and about how others think as well. Really helpful knowledge for just becoming a more understanding person who realizes why humans are sometimes quick to judge/think something, teaches students how we can work together to create a more understanding, equal society
I learned how to think about myself and those around me and understand the processes underlying thoughts and feelings.
A good base knowledge of into psychology.
Comprehensive survey of the various subfields within psychology
Thinking about humans, emotions, application
In this course, I learned how to read psychology studies and analyze them, and I learned many useful facts about our daily lives.
Learned about a broad range of topics in psychology. Learned how to pull away the importance of case studies.
General survey of psychology as a study.
Quick note taking, content specific to course, how to study for multiple choice exams
Knowledge of basic principles of psychology and how they apply in everyday life.
I learned about human behavior
I learned about the basics of psychology, and have actually found that I have begun to use these facts and study results in my own life.
I learned a lot about how the mind works.
Introductory psych
I was offered a broad survey of relevant topics in psychology and learned how they have a practical value in everyday life.
Basic overview of psychology
This course taught me how to apply some general principles of psychology to my daily life, in order to get to know myself and others better.

Psychology is an amazing field that affects our daily lives without us realizing it. I learned how to properly write a psychology paper and improve my writing skills, whether it be vocabulary wise, argument wise, etc.
Basic psychology and some interesting fun psychological facts.
I learned the basics of psychology from the course. The course was interesting since Dean Chun presented many interesting experiments during lecture.
A broad knowledge of psych
That we are all psychologists in our own right.
I reinforced the knowledge I acquired in AP Psychology during high school.

I really enjoyed that this class was focused a lot on psychology research studies. It really put the definitions and terms in perspective and I'll remember the studies in the future much more than the terms.
I learned about the inner-workings of the mind.
I learned more about what specifically interests me in psychology. Also, I learned how to write less speculative in my scientific reports.
Survey of psychological subjects, including personality, disorders, drugs, addiction, methods of study, etc. We touched on behavioral, cognitive, and other branches of psychology.
I learned about everyday, applicable psychology
this course helped me understand the principles of psychology
The course has helped to systemize the knowledge of psychology. Besides that, I learned a lot about various interesting studies and effects.
I learned the basics of psychology and the ways it plays into our everyday lives.

I learned a lot about concepts that could be related to the world outside, such as why people behave as they do, different psychological disorders, and connections socially and biologically to many different concepts.
I learned a lot about the way people think and function in society.
Basic psychology principles.
How to think critically about human behavior
General overview of psychology topics and experiments
I learned the history of psychology as well as many of the general theories, experiments, and ideas associated with the science.
About the basics of psychology

I learned so much about so many different areas of psychology and about how those areas have developed and changed course over the past century or so. I also gained insight into the current topics of psychology research and about how to critically read psychology journal papers.
Creative thinking, relating what I learned in the classroom to my personal life etc.
None. This course was virtually useless and devoid of any important information.
I learned a great overview of psychology!

I developed a pretty comprehensive knowledge of basic psychology and feel like the course layout covered a bunch of different areas within the field. It didn't focus too heavily on one concept or lesson, so I feel like I got a very wide variety of skills and knowledge.
Learned the fundamentals of psychology, as it relates to neuroscience and social psychology
a basic understanding of psychology
Cool facts about human bias and human memory, as well as knowledge of brain imaging technology and its potential use.
I learned how to study well for classes that require memorization for large amounts of material. This class also allowed me to determine whether I wanted to take other psychology courses.
A great amount of knowledge of psychological processes and terminology. Also got insight in how psychological research works by participating in research programs.
It's an intro psych course, so we learned the basics of psych.
An introductory understanding towards the field of psychology

I gained SO much from this course! Whether that was understanding etiology of disorders, the reason for our human behaviors, how we come to learn and socialize with one another, or dissecting one's preferences and biases, Intro to Psych was a pivotal course in solidifying my passions and career goals.
Psychology insights that were very helpful
basic psychology and how I can apply them into my daily life.
I gained a good introduction to how psychology is viewed in an academic context.
I learned the basics of psychology.
Introduction to psychology.

What is the goal of this class? Is the goal of this class to make students puppets of yale and for us to make yale larger than it is, for us to be blind to its flaws? Or is the purpose of this class to understand psychology as a science that can complement and challenge so-called "future leaders of the world?" Yale is wonderful precisely because it is so flawed. We make mistakes, we have implicit biases, we follow the group, we do what's comfortable.  psychology helps us understand why the above are true.
I learned a lot of interesting things that can sometimes be applied to everyday life, which genuinely surprised me.
A breadth of knowledge about the basics of Psychology.
Learned a lot about psychology and myself

I learned about many different topics in psychology, from personality to development to intelligence. I also got to delve into research on my own on certain topics to expand on what we covered in class. I would say I developed a lot of insights about humans and how they think that are very relevant to everyday life.
I gained a vast amount of knowledge that I can apply to everyday life to make myself a more happy (and thus successful) person.

I learnt how Psychology can be applied to many aspects of life such as relationships and decision making and I also learnt how to write research papers on various topics and how to navigate scientific literature.
I developed some basic understanding and knowledge of experimental procedures in psychology, basic psychology, how to read psychology papaers effectively and some that linked to neuroscience.
I learned the basics of psychology! A lot of loose facts here and there, but each fact is very memorable and perfect for a "Did you know..." moment!
I developed a broad understanding of a lot of interesting concepts and questions in psychology and how experiments/studies are generally conducted to answer these questions.

This course was a comprehensive introduction to psychology that covered a broad spectrum of topics. The core value of the course, that we are all psychologists and that psychology is prevalent in our everyday lives clearly resonated through the themes of the lectures and the presentation of concepts. This course really made me realize how passionate I am for different aspects of psychology and certainly prompted me to engage myself with psychology more during the rest of my college career. I got to understand the underlying foundations of various behavioral traits, and I got to analyze various situations and understand how psychology can help us shed light on them. Through this course, I realized that psychology is relatable and applicable to our everyday life. Interpreting the world around us through the lenses of psychology  was certainly a central aspect of this course, and I am happy that I was able to do that and to gain so much insight into our world and behavior by taking this course.
I learned about psychology - namely, conditions that affect the brain, and ways to use psychology to improve life. I also learned quite a few things about Dean Chun.
I gained a better understanding of the cognitive processes behind the mind of my own and others. Also, I learned about the science of psychology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Sometimes PollEv would not work and time would be spent waiting for the connection to stabilize.
Professor Chun was charismatic, and the research requirement provided a great opportunity to get exposed to psych research and learn about ongoing research projects.

Strengths: All the lecture slides were posted, and there wasn't really much day-to-day homework.
Weakness: The textbook readings did not exactly match the lecture material and therefore was a bit disconnected. Also textbook readings were a lot sometimes, and since they didn't overlap, then it was actually quite a bit of content to review before every exam.

I think the tests/papers could be better organized. Students werent really instructed/pushed towards whats important to know (salty because I studied the things thatd be important to know in our actual lives and we were often tested on things that arent applicable to our lives).
Interesting course content.

Strengths: great lecture! Loved teaching style of Professor Chun; also enjoyed the structure of the class being spread out with readings, short papers, and exams
Weaknesses: none!

Strengths: Marvin Chun is a great lecturer. He speaks clearly, funny, and his slides are clear and organized. He makes the lectures interesting and relevant. 

Weaknesses: The TF grading for the papers can feel a bit arbitrary. However, the papers aren't worth much, so it probably won't affect your grade much in the end anyways. Also, the textbook readings can be dry.

Mix: the guest lecturers. Some were incredible (esp. Peter Salovey and Laurie Santos), but others were less so.

I think one of the strengths of the course was how engaging it was. Professor Chun included relevant ideas and videos in each lecture in addition to polleverywhere which kept everyone very engaged. The material is also all relevant to our everyday lives! I think one of the weaknesses was how disjoint all of the lectures were and also the guest lecturers were not as engaging as Professor Chun.

The strengths of this class were that Dean Chun brought in a lot of guest lecturers who were experts in their field. One of the weaknesses of the class was that I felt Dean Chun had his hands tied by being dean and teaching the class at the same time. He spent way too much time talking about how the studies conducted assumed a gender binary, and he shied away from getting in to more controversial studies regarding differences in gender.

strength: great instructing, interesting, all resources on canvas, very good textbook
- text book did bring up interesting context, but maybe the level of importance of the each text book topics should have been pointed out more, since some sections seemed unnecessary and weren't tested, but some were. More overlap/discussion of the textbook would have been helpful.
Strengths include guest lecturers. Weakness is the very large size of the coarse and random grading on essays by the TAs.

Weaknesses: too big of a class, small level of interaction, frequent technical difficulties, lecture slides difficult to follow

Strengths: some good guest speakers, video recordings of lectures

Ways to improve: shorter lecture slides (30-40 slides max), and more time spent on each slide

The strengths of this course are the material that you learn and the way that it applies to your everyday life. A weakness of this course was that due to its size, it was hard to feel like you could interact with the professor and ask questions during lecture.
Marvin Chun is a great lecturer, and there's not a lot to improve.

Sometimes, the concepts were not explained as well as they could have been. The text was highly informative, filled with a ton of information that was not very relevant. Nevertheless, we were required to read them because small parts of them would be tested on in the midterms.

Strengths: super engaging, great professor, good balance between textbook info and his own info, not too much work

Weaknesses: a lot of material (but still worth it!)
There is little interaction with the TA's which is unfortunate. Professor Chun however is amazing!

The amount of material in which we as students have to get through between the textbook and in-class notes is a LOT. I feel like this course could do without the textbook since within lecture we go over the most significant material anyway. I also think the papers were graded much harder than they should've been and it wasn't fair that the average grade given out to people was supposed to be a 6, instead of trying to give students as many points back/as much credit as their work deserves.

Strength: riveting lectures, great material
Weakness: tricky exams

The lectures are really interesting and engaging. The readings were not. Taking this course Credit/D and focusing mostly on the lectures made the calss a lot more enjoyable for me.

The papers in this class felt unnecessary - the topics were too broad and didn't really contribute to my understanding of the materiel.
The course lectures very engaging and relevant but the readings are long and not all the material on the reading is tested.

Marvin made it subjectively more difficult than any other time this course was taught. It was supposed to be an introductory class and he made it way more difficult than introductory level classes. He also made the information a lot about himself and Yale's accomplishments rather than actual psychology.

Strengths of this course is that the material is super interesting and Dean Chun, and basically any psychology professor at Yale, is best in their field. The class is large so there can be cool class polling and interactions with the studies. But this is also the weakness; since the class is so large, you begin to feel more like a number in the system for them.
Lectures were very engaging. Expectations were very clear. The exams were short and on the easier side since many questions were repeated from the practice exams.
The material was very interesting and the workload was manageable as long as you stayed on top of your work. Not many weaknesses, it was one of my favorite courses at my time at Yale.

Obviously Dean Chun is a good lecturer. There was somewhat limited help I guess. The requirements for the papers were somewhat unclear at the beginning of the semester. "Good writing" seemed to be way more important than the actual criteria laid forth. The lectures were interesting. The exams were a comfortable level of easy/hard. It just wasn't spectacular. Just average I guess, but I couldn't tell you why. The lab requirment was really fun though. I learned a lot from them and they were really interesting.
Marvin was engaging but the class was too easy and there wasnt enough hw to keep people continually engaged

Despite being a lecture, this was actually a fantastic course that I really enjoyed. I feel like I learned so much that was so applicable to my everyday life and to my interactions with other people. Having taken this class I feel like I understand not only myself better, but also the people and the world around me.

i felt like i was tested on the content of random studies presented in class, i dont feel that i came out with much general knowledge of psychology. i feel the tests were oddly specific, making it difficult to succeed.
Weakness is that lectured get continuously a little boring. Strengths is that overall lectures are interesting. Weakness is that papers were very obscure and subjective when it came to grading.
The lectures were good. I liked participating in the studies. Otherwise was a fairly basic intro course.
Large lecture has its downsides. It's easy to stop paying attention. But all lectures are recorded and put online so that was very very helpful.

Dean Chun is incredibly engaging lecturer, keeps students interested for majority of a 75-minute lecture which is impressive! Some guest lecturers were very interesting, others not so much, but a lot of that is based on the teaching style of the particular instructor. 

Because it is a broad survey course, the class does not get into any topic, field, or question beyond a very superficial, surface level. Of course, that's because there is a lot of material to cover across different topics in a short time, but for someone looking for a deeper dive, a higher-level seminar in psychology could be more interesting (though this class will likely be a prerequisite!)

Lectures sometimes felt disjointed jumping from one topic to a completely different one, but overall very engaging for a huge introductory class. Generous grading for the most part as well.
The guest lecturers were a great way to learn the material and about the lecturer's work at Yale.

Strengths: broad range of topics and very interesting lecture topics that balanced technicality and generalization well. Good feedback from graduate students on essays.
To improve: The order of topics was rather confusing, especially since textbook chapters rarely aligned with lectures.

The lab requirement was a lot. I think requiring fewer credits would be helpful, especially since they aren't even graded. Also, the readings were just too much. 99% of the textbook readings assigned were not tested, but you couldn't predict what would be, so it was best to read all of it just in case. But at the same time, I felt like a lot of my time was wasted on reading useless information.

Professor Chun was a strength of the course!

I think one of the strengths was that, for certain topics, guest lecturers who specialize in those topics were brought in to teach them. I think this greatly improved the quality of learning since we were learning from experts in that specific area. A weakness may be that the lecture feels impersonal but it is unavoidable when the course has so many students taking it.

Strengths - really applicable to the real world, really interesting, taught very well
Weaknesses - a little difficult to know what information was important for tests and papers

marvin is quite flustery and frenetic, stuttering a lot which makes it harder to focus and decreases students' engagement during the lectures. There could be better feedback given on the papers, and more help in reviewing for the exams.
The lecture style was challenging however Mr. Chun made the environment interactive.

This course's strength is in its teaching, particularly Dean Chun, who really makes an effort to help students understand and learn psychology. He often incorporates new psychological research into his lectures that give a nuanced interpretation of the discipline. Dean Chun's lectures are very interesting and I always left class knowing that I had learned something new. A weakness of this course is the lab requirement, which although it was very interesting, was never emphasized throughout the course. Many students had forgotten about it by the end, leaving them scrambling to fulfill it. Another weakness is the feedback given on papers  which I did not find to be particularly helpful for improving my grade on future papers.
Pole everywhere was a weakness that wasted a lot of time.  It was engaging because of having many guest professors, interactive elements (class participation) and music at the beginning.
The lectures were great and engaging, polleverywhere hardly ever worked though but Im not sure how much can be done to fix that
Professor Chun was a very engaging lecturer, and the information was topical.  The downside of the class was that the readings were dense and boring.
Sometimes it felt like I was just memorizing fun facts for the tests. I am not sure what could be done about this. Also, some of the guest lectures were less engaging than Prof. Chun.
The quiz app rarely worked
The instructions for papers felt incredibly vague.
Sometimes lectures felt disorganized. Dean Chun is very funny though and enthusiastic about the material.

Lectures were extremely engaging and I learned a lot from them. In other classes I hardly learn from lecture at all, but this class was great.

One weakness was that there was some highly debatable leftist opinions thrown in, but compared to other Yale classes it was not too much.
The lecturer is good but the course is very broad and moves quickly.
I loved how engaging the material was.
Extremely well-organized. Marvin Chun is wonderful!
Good lectures

Only weakness is the amount of reading does not justify how few textbook only questions showed up on the test. You could not read the book and perform average if you really study the lectures, but just to get those few points you have to skim hundreds of pages of reading.
Sometimes the information presented in class seemed tangential and a bit like a bad standup routine. On the whole however the class was well paced and had many interesting guest lectures.
Some of the lectures were a bit boring. The guest lectures in particular ranged from very engaging (Santos, Salovey) to not engaging at all.
Integrate the textbook a little more to incentivize reading on time

I love the course. The material was very engaging and covered wide variety of topics. I would say the only weakness is that tests cover a lot of material, some of which can seem unrelated to each other,  especially because the textbook chapters focus on different materials the materials.

This course was effective in surveying the various foundations of psychology - the textbook was especially helpful in this regard. However, there were serious problems with the content taught in the class, both in terms of its accuracy and its relevance. In terms of the former, it must be noted that psychology is a scientific field like every other, and its legitimacy is totally compromised when the conclusions of the discipline are contorted to gel with whatever positions are politically, socially, or culturally dominant. We must determine first determine what is true and subsequently revise our folk conceptions of human behavior to accord with this true, not the other way around. I fear that this class did not do this effectively. In controversial topics where psychological science has nonetheless generated pretty clear conclusions (the nature of intelligence, gender differences as a product of culture or nature, etc.), this class did an inadequate job of sticking to the science in spite of what is politically hip. This is by no means easy to do, but it certainly must be done nevertheless if a scientific discipline is to take itself seriously. Additionally, this class seemed to have something of an identity crisis in deciding whether it was an Intro Psych class or a generic version of Laurie Santos's "Psychology and the Good Life." In trying to be both, it never quite became either. 

All too often, when the class should have been learning the basic foundations of the psychological discipline, we were too busy being told that sleep is good, stress is bad, and that studying social phenomena with a gender binary renders the information of the study "outdated." The opportunity cost of teaching this information is high. In the future, I hope that this course is taught with a closer alignment to the science of the field and an explicit rebuke of the idea that our political and ideological presuppositions should inform pursuits of scientific truth.

Lectures were extremely fascinating and I learned a lot of surprising things and the science behind a lot of psychological concepts. This course's strength was certainly its instructor and the way in which he engaged students with the topics that were discussed in lecture. Marvin Chun was an amazing lecturer who had an infectious passion for the subjects that he was teaching. The guest lecturers were also a very interesting aspect of this course, as they brought in different viewpoints and talked about various issues from the standpoint of a specialist. The breadth and depth of topics that the course covered allowed for a comprehensive, yet interesting introduction to psychology. For me, the experimental part of the course seemed somewhat unnecessary. Specifically, I believe that this part of the course did not offer a substantial understanding of the reasons behind the experiments or the specific nature of the experimental setups. I did not feel that I learned from participating in these experiments. Rather, I felt as a subject that was "used" for the purpose of research without that actually adding to my learning within the spectrum of the course. Furthermore, the papers may at times have seemed disjointed from the topics that were covered in lecture, and the fact that we had no clear outline of how to write a paper in psychology within lecture, certainly created this environment of ambiguity when it came to the assignments. I acknowledge that an outline for how to structure a paper was available to us online; however, that does not compare with an overview from the instructor during lecture.

I thought the course was well organized in the logistical sense. The relationship between the Professor, TFs, classroom participation (PollEV), and the lab participation process was all very smooth. However, the curriculum was not very well organized. It was unclear how the topics in each lecture related to each other, and there was not a clear central theme to the class. Also, it was incredibly difficult to know how to study for the exams, as there was a lot of information from the textbook that was tested but not taught in class.

Strengths: fun interactive in-class polls to demonstrate key psych concepts, lectures based on empirical evidence/studies that augment textbook material
Weaknesses: sometimes lecture material was not organized in a clear and logical manner, which I guess is a result of not following the book

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Ya boiiiiiiii
Absolutely. Chun is a terrific lecturer and the guest lecture circuit was fascinating.
I would recommend this course to another student because it was interesting and rewarding.
No

Yes. It was a pretty great introductory class for learning about psychology. I do feel like I learned a massive amount of information on how the mind and human behavior works and also learned about a lot of the famous studies. It is, however, a bit more work that you might expect, just because textbook readings were a lot. But if you keep up with them, then it's manageable and won't be so difficult to learn it all before the exam.
Probably not. I think psychology is important to learn but not necessarily when its structured this way.
Yes. Good introduction to psychology.
Definitely! Even if you aren't a psych/related major, this class is so much fun, especially with friends!

I would definitely recommend this course. You gain an introduction to major psychological findings, and it's taught by a great lecturer: Professor Chun. The material is mostly really interesting, and Professor Chun makes it relevant to our everyday lives; people want to come to lecture. The readings take, on average, 2-3 hours per week, so it's not that much work. There are three 2-3 page papers and 3 midterms. There is a fair amount of memorization to do for each test, but it's definitely doable; overall, it's a relatively low workload class.

I would definitely recommend this course. As somebody who didn't take AP Psych in high school, I really enjoyed learning about famous studies and influential psych theories that influence my everyday life. It isn't a huge workload either, but there is a lot of material on each midterm.
I would recommend the class but with a different professor. I had high expectations going in to the class, but other students regularly pointed out wrong information that was given during class.

Definitely, because interesting contents, good textbook that is enjoyable, interesting, even amusing to read, good instructing, many topics, so chance that some are interesting to a student is higher. No final exam, but contents spread over non-cumulative midterm exams.
Yes. Especially going into finance and business, the psychology classes are very relatable and applicable.

If you really really enjoy learning psych, you should take it. That being said, if you're looking for a gut, this is not the class for you. Retaining the subject material can be challenging, especially if you're not fully invested in the class.

I really wanted to love this class. However, it didn't meet my (admittedly lofty) expectations for a number of reasons. First, the lectures. I was expecting to be blown away. On the first day of class, Prof. Chun teased us with a lineup of all of the superstar faculty we'd be getting guest lectures from that semester, from Laurie Santos to Peter Salovey. And on the days we didn't get guest lecturers, we'd have to settle for a world-renowned neuropsychologist and the dean of Yale College. However, the guest lectures varied wildly in quality. It was almost absurd. Some of them were phenomenal. Salovey's, in particular, was the best lecture I've ever watched in my entire life. Others were snore-inducing. In the middle of this wide, wide spectrum was Prof. Chun. Although he was a good lecturer, it became clear over the course of the semester that his decanal duties were affecting the quality of his lectures. In fact, he admitted it, saying, "It doesn't feel like it used to," and then blaming it the slides that he posted before class. Sorry, honey, it's not the slides, it's you. Regardless, it was overwhelmingly apparent that he cared about us and wanted us to be wow-ed by psychology. Which brings me to the assessments. I don't think the assessments were reflective of the spirit of the class at all. The exams were all about memorizing studies and vocabulary terms, which is fine, but is that really what Prof. Chun wanted us to take away from the class? A bunch of vocabulary terms that we'd forget as soon as we walked out of the exam room door? I doubt it. Finally, the order of the lectures really needs to be revamped. Save Salovey and Santos for last. I feel like we hit the best of the class a month in and the rest of it was just a slog.
I think Intro Psych is an incredibly useful class to take regardless of your major due to the way it is truly used in everyday life.
Yep! It's super fun.
If you want a broad intro level psychology course, sure why not. Some of the concepts were cool.
Yes! If you are even slightly interested in psychology but dont know what parts of it, take this course and you will probably find your niche.
Yes for sure if you want to learn about the basics of psychology
Yes, Dean Chun was very engaging during lectures, so it was actually quite fun.
For sure. Best course I've ever taken, and the lectures are incredible.
Yes, especially with Marvin Chun.
Not if Marvin Chun is teaching it. He's interesting and a great teacher, but made this course so much more difficult than it was in years past.
Yes! Psychology can be applied to everything.
Yes! If you're at all interested in psychology, you will learn a lot!
Yes, it is a great class to take even if you aren't a prospective psychology major. It teaches you a lot of information that is applicable to the real world. Very entertaining and well-taught class.
Yes. It's comprehensive and fun.
Sure. If you've never taken a psych class before, it's interesting and a good introduction to the subject. Marvin Chun is great to get a lecture from. It wasn't an experience, but it was fun.
Yeh i would. it was pretty interesting and fun and not too much work and tough to do bad
I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if Marvin Chun is teaching the class. Intro Psychology is a must if you are human being living on the planet earth.
Definitely! It was such a fun class. I always looked forward to lecture and was always very engaged. The assignments are very manageable and there is always very clear feedback.
no, it is not a good way to learn psychology
Yes, it aS very interesting and not too much of a workload.
Yes, I found it interesting especially as someone with no psych background.
It's interesting and worth going, just easy to miss a lecture and then stop caring.

I would recommend it if you intend to take more psychology courses. I think it's a great introduction and sets you up for the rest of the classes in the major. It also focuses on research psychology which is very interesting and definitely drew me to the field.

For a student with NO prior experience in psychology AND needs this as a prerequisite (ie, if you are a psych major), it's definitely worth it

However, if you're planning on just taking one psych course, I would recommend trying to get into a more specific seminar

Yes. This is a good introduction to psychology that presents engaging topics and memorable studies without an overwhelming degree of detail. If they had previously taken psychology (as I had), the pace may be a bit slow, but there is enough new information and interpretations to keep the class engaging.
Yes. This class wasn't too challenging and it was fun to take. The lectures were also really great. I loved the guest lecture series, especially the love lecture given by President Peter Salovey.
Yes because I feel like a basic knowledge of this stuff is important no matter what your major is

I would recommend taking this course if you are interested in psychology but do not want to delve too deep into it. The course is great for learning about various topics in psychology but does not really go indepth into any of them (which makes sense).
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It's a lot of fun to take - the lectures are genuinely interesting - and you learn a lot.
yes, I learned a lot for an Introduction to Psychology course. This definitely is not a gut however, and should be taken seriously.
Yes if they want to learn about why they do what they do.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in psychology, but may not want to major in it. I truly believe that this course is for everyone who is willing to put in the effort. The class is definitely not easy, but it is manageable. I feel that many of the lessons I learned became very relevant to my everyday life and I found myself with a better understanding of some of society's most pressing issues such as drug addiction and personality and mental disorders. If you want a course that will teach you about real life, this is the one!
yes.
Yes, a good course with information that is relevant to many other subject areas.
Yes, psychology is something used on everyday life and this class does a great job of showing that.
If you are interested at all in psychology, or plan to major in it, I would definitely take this class. You will have to put significant effort in to receive a good grade, as with any Yale course.
I think it was an overall good experience. Sometimes studying for the tests felt like busy-work, but I don't think that can be avoided. They wanted us to succeed, and we learned a lot of cool things.
yes! very well taught
Yes

Absolutely. This is a great SO and survey of psychology. You dont go too in depth on any topic and its fun to talk about lots of different things.
Yes, good class if you need a social science.
Yes I would recommend this course because it applies to the real world
Yes. I absolutely loved this course. It was very interesting.

I would probably recommend this course to another student as it was well-run and is a prerequisite for more advanced psychology classes, but I didn't learn as much as I thought I would (probably because I've gone to a lot of therapy in my life and also frequently listen to NPR).

Yep. Good class.
Good overview of psychology, interesting for people with a minor interest in psychology and interesting for people who have to take it for the major so I would recommend.
Yes, but if its possible for you to place out with your AP score, do it.
Yeah I enjoyed it
I definitely would!
Yes, it was an interesting class

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in taking psychology. It is an intro course though, so it is a lot of information to grasp that you make not be familiar with if you've never taken psychology. There may even be people with experience that you're competing with.

I would - this is a good way to fulfill a social sciences credit for a STEM student, and Dean Chun is a wonderful professor.
Yes. It is good if you are curious about psychology in a general sense.
I would because psychology is needed to help reduce stress.

I found this course to be incredibly interesting and comprehensive introduction to psychology, and would definitely recommend to anyone who isn't scared off by the thick textbook readings that one has to do for each exam. Marvin Chun is a great (albeit sometimes awkward) lecturer, and the energy that he brought to class was always incredible.
I would so the student could learn more about a different subject.

Yes but I feel like it was poorly organized in terms of what went into exams

I took it for credit in the cogsci major. You wont get that much out of it so its better to take a higher level psych course if you really want to learn. This course is fairly easy though, easier than they make it seem.
I would certainly recommend this course, its a must take whenever Marvin Chun is offering it.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in a wide overview of topics in psychology. I think much of the knowledge in the class is pretty practical for everyday life which is really fun. Be aware, however, that the course is a substantial amount of work and does dive into the material in great detail which may be hard to get over unless youre interested in psychology, especially since reading the textbook is important for exams.

It can be a really fun lecture class. I liked what we learned and it was never an extremely stressful class. Dean Chun also has a lot of guest lecturers who were great and added a new dimension to the course.

Yes! I really appreciate Dean Chun putting a lot of effort for each lecture, and I really like the TAs!
Yes, very interesting and applicable universally.
Yes! Especially with Dean Chun.
Yes, I believe the subject matter is necessary for all aspects of life
Yes
To take a class with Dean Chun, yes. For enjoyment, no.
I would recommend this course! I learnt a lot about the human mind, and all majors could benefit from taking this course!

Yes - I would definitely recommend taking this course with Marvin Chun. He was a great and engaging lecturer, and all of the exams were administered and graded fairly. If you study the lectures and read the textbook, studying some of the key terms, you should do just fine on the exams (which often look similar to past ones). It's also just a very interesting subject that is relevant to everyday life, so I would recommend that everyone take into psych. We had three short papers this semester (500-800 words) that were focused on a topic and research based so the more you engage with research the higher grade you would get. The lab requirement was the biggest nuisance - you essentially had to attend/participate in 5 hour-long studies throughout the semester. It wasn't hard and some of them were really interesting, but I'd recommend spacing them out (online ones won't pop up much).
If youre looking for a broad intro to psych, I think it delivers, and it was fun to take it with Marvin Chun
Yes, very interesting class for anyone really.

Yes - I certainly walked out of the class knowing more about psychology than I did walking in. However, some of this information (as I have described earlier) was extremely misleading, and undoubtedly led to the wrong conclusions being drawn in the minds of many who were formerly unacquainted with the discipline. Thus, I would advise students to take this class, but with a skeptical and cautious eye. Factcheck claims that strike you as outlandish or important enough to change some relevant opinion of yours.

Yes! The information is so valuable and interesting even if you are not interested in psych. It is so cool to learn about the reasons we do what we do, especially when related to current problems. I found so many connections between the things I learned in this class and information in my other classes, which was so cool.
Eh... I already knew most things or could at least intuit them. But I enjoyed learning from Marvin. And did pick up some cool facts about psychology.
Yes, for someone esp an underclassmen who wants a low stress intro course thats still interesting
I would reccomend this class to anyone interested in understanding the broad mechanisms of various types of psychology
Yes!!! So interesting even if you dont want to be a psych major

Yes, I would. I think its important for every student to take this course. It really opened up a new perspective for me on evaluating conflicts with others and with myself. I found it to be very applicable to life with makes it all the more worth it.

yes

Yes. Professor Chun is an amazing lecturer and he knows how to engage the audience. I think everyone should take this class once in their Yale career.

This class is an absolute GEM that I recommend ANYONE take. Professor (Dean) Chun does a fantastic job making the content that we learn applicable to the real world while keeping the lectures funny and engaging. I took this class to fill my social sciences requirement and it turned out to be one of my favorite classes of my semester. I think that anyone who is looking to fulfill the requirements and/or has even the slightest interest in psychology should take this course! This is, in my opinion, one of the best classes I've taken at Yale.

I should mention, if you do the textbook readings (which honestly don't take that much time, maybe 1-2 hours a week) and the research papers (take more time, but only 3x a semester) the workload honestly isn't that bad. And if you do that, getting an A in the class/high grade is very easy. The best part about this class, though, is that PSYC 110 is one of those rare classes where you don't put in a ton of work, but you learn a ton.

I would recommend this course to another student as a way to learn about psychology, which is super useful in real life! This is definitely a class that I quote all the time when I talk to other people and the insights you gain from this class are super valuable.

yes

I feel that this course provides students with a very interesting, holistic, and comprehensive understanding of psychology, while it is fundamentally enjoyable and interesting in every sense. The instructor is amazing and he does a great job in making sure that the core theme of the course (that we are all psychologists and that psychology is relatable) is constantly underlined and outlined in lectures. There are always interesting examples that are used to frame specific psychological principles, something that adds to the interest that the course elicits.

I don't know. I will be taking cognitive science next year, and based on what I've heard I wouldn't recommend this class to anyone who is on the cognitive science track because it covers many of the same topics as intro to Cog Sci, but to a more shallow depth.
Yes! It's an engaging way to get introduced to psych.
